key_title: Key to the species of Eleocharis

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Cyperaceae

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Glumes 7–11 mm long, coriaceous, finely many-nerved with distinct midrib, not at all or only obscurely keeled; spikelet not much wider than culm
Glumes less than 5 mm long, membranous with distinct midrib, often distinctly keeled, sides nerveless; spikelet distinctly wider than culm unless the latter is flat
Style 2-fid; mouth of leaf-sheath never mucronate
Style 3-fid, or rarely 2-fid in E. pallens and E. acuta and then the mouth of the uppermost leaf-sheath transverse and prominently mucronate
External surface of the nut longitudinally ridged, the intervening cells transversely linear or oblong; nut obscurely trigonous or terete

Surface of nut finely reticulate, wrinkled, pitted or smooth, the cells very small and often very faint, mostly shortly vertically oblong in very numerous series; nut distinctly trigonous or lenticular
Nut obpyriform, with c. 8 prominent ridges on each face; culm surface with circular to elliptic cell outlines in longitudinal columns (obvious at X 20 magnification
Nut narrow-obovoid to obovoid, with 3–5 prominent ridges on each face; culm surface smooth on and between ribs
Spikelet narrow-ovoid to linear, 10–20 mm long, rarely producing fruit; glumes 3–5 mm long; plants often proliferating and producing tubers; glumes red-brow
Spikelet ovoid, 2–7 mm long, usually setting fruit; glumes 2.0–2.5 mm long; plants neither proliferating nor with tubers; glumes dark red-brown to blackish
Nut biconvex or plano-convex; mouth of leaf-sheath truncate and mucronate
Nut  trigonous; mouth of leaf-sheath oblique, usually not mucronate

Rhizome very short; culms densely tufted; nut with ± prominently ribbed angles; anther appendage not exceeding 0.15 mm in length; glumes readily deciduous; culms strongly longitudinally ridged (obvious at least when dried) with surface minutely reticulate and glistening between ridges
Rhizome creeping; nut not strongly ribbed on the angles; anthers with apical appendage c. 0.2 mm long; glumes tardily deciduous; culms faintly striate or obscurely wrinkled, otherwise smooth

Culms terete or nearly so, ± trigonous immediately below the spikelet (may be flattened when dried, and then mucro at mouth of leaf-sheath may be in any position relative to 'margins' of flattened culm); spikelet often much wider than culm
Culms strongly flattened when fresh, even at apex; mucro at mouth of leaf-sheaths always at middle of one flat face of culm; spikelet slightly wider than culm
Plants not more than 5 cm high, extensively stoloniferous or rhizomatous, almost turf-like and producing copious small tubers; spikelets less than 5 mm long
Plants more than 5 cm high, tufted or shortly rhizomatous, never turf-like, tubers lacking or rare; spikelets longer than 5 mm
Nut more or less evenly trigonous with ribbed dorsal angle; hypogynous bristles retrorsely toothed,  equal, as long as or longer than nut
Nut unevenly trigonous, with the dorsal angle not ribbed; hypogynous bristles smooth, uneven, up to half the length of nut
